data.title: 1804 St Maria Catholic Church listing Smyrna
data.text:
Ephemera

1804 St Maria Catholic Church Smyrna listing

This listing was drawn up by the priest in charge of the church St Maria in 1804, which was the Catholic church in Smyrna protected by the Austrian Emperor, in order to identify the families attending his church versus the families attending the nearby Catholic church St Polycarpe (church under France protection). Therefore some family names are not correctly spelled, especially the French ones as the priest was Italian, and the document is written in that language. Besides these 2 Catholic churches, there was a Catholic church in Bornova and another one in Buca existing at that time.

The original document is in Rome in the archives of the Congregation of the propogation of faith (Archivio della Congregazione di Propaganda Fide - Fondo S. C. Smirne Vol. 2).

Key / Abreviations used:

sign. = Signor = Mr

mog. (moglie) = wife

ser. = servant

nip. (nipote) = grandchildren (but also nephew and niece)

Ill. = Illustrissimo = most illustrious (especially as belonging to the Italian aristocracy)

veda (ved.a) = widow

nuora = daughter-in-law

fig = figlio = son / God child

figli dâanima = adopted child

cognata = sister-in-law

It is striking how many of these family names are still represented in Izmir today over 200 years after this listing was created. The term ânationalityâ is problematic here and perhaps a better substitution would be origin.

Notes:

1- There are a further 15 entries whose surnames could not be deciphered, so not listed here.

2- There are possibilities of dual entries as some surnames and forenames and other details mostly match in some cases, such as Giovanni di Francesco, Giovanni di Giacomo, Pavolo di Giovanni, Pietro di Pavolo (3 times), Andrea di Tomaso (3), Francesco Manusso, M. Michele Palamari, Antonio Psalti, Rolland (?), Vedova Roubaud.

3- There are 446 entries recorded here (ignoring the 15 where names are absent) and of those in descending order these are the professions:

Broker (Sensali, 61), Merchant (52), Dragoman (11), Tailor (Sartori, 10), Shoe-maker (Calzolaj, 10), Clerk (Scrivano / Scritturale, 10), Baker (Fornacini, 6), Grocer (Bottegajo, 5), Hairdresser (Parrucchieri, 4), Clerk of the Consulate or of the Court (Cancelliere, 4), Doctor (Medici, 4), Surgeon (Chirurgi, 4), Store keeper (Magasiniere, 3), Watch maker (Orologiere, 3), Lawyer (Avvocati, 3), Cafe owner (Cafettieri, 2), Inn keeper (Locandieri, 2), Tin smith (Stagnaio, 2), Second-hand dealer (Rigattiere, 2), Gunsmith (Armajolo, 2), Secretary (Segretario, 1), Herbalist (Erborajo, 1), Silversmith (Argentiere, 1), Jeweller (Giojeliere, 1), Taverna owner (Tavernaio, 1), Cashier (Cassiere, 1). There are 34 entries for paupers (Poveri).

4- Nationality / origin is not a fixed designation as it is today as often members of the same family had different nationalities and this is particularly problematic when designating Eastern origin Levantines designated as Orientals, Alepins, Persians etc. The breakdown from this listing:

French (88), Persian (97 - often lumped as Persan-Alepin-Damas), Tinos (82 - often lumped as Tignotti, Naxiotti, Siriotti), Chios (44), Austrian (43), Ragusin (21), Dutch (16), Spanish / Neapolitan (15), Scottish (14 - Sciotti), English (14), Oriental (5), Smyrna (perhaps meaning mixed heritage, 3), Russian (Moscovite, 1)

5- Going on an average of 4 persons per entry, we can see the standing community of the St Maria Church at the time was around 1,800. There would have been around 4 Catholic churches in Smyrna at the time, so the âLatinâ community of the city would have been around 7.000 as a crude approximation. This population would increase significantly during the 19th century.

6- There is a possibility the priest who drew up this listing was not a ânativeâ Italian speaker, many were of Croatian etc. origin. Many of the nationalities were written in French and the spelling of a lot of the professions done in Italian is incorrect: Calzolaj= Calzolaio, Dragomani= Dragomanni, Giojaliere= Gioielliere, Bottegaj= Bottegaio, Avvocati= Avvocato, Magasiniere= Magazziniere, Chirurgi espeziali = Chirurgo e speziale, Cancelaria = Cancelleria, Sartori = Sarto.
